page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

===4 February â Friday of Departure===

+
[[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "Friday of Departure"]]
  +
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A tank at the entrance to Tahrir Square]]
The organizers of the "Day of Revolt" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February as their deadline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
The organizers of the "Day of Revolt" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February as their deadline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/03/live-blog-feb-4-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 4 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/03/live-blog-feb-4-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 4 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
â
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A tank at the entrance to Tahrir Square]]
 
Two million Egyptians flooded Tahrir Square to participate in Friday prayer in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=235172|title=2 million Egyptians turn out for Day of Departure|publisher=[[Tehran Times]]|date=2011-02-05|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> [[Egyptian Christians]] and others not performing Friday prayers formed a "human chain" around those praying to protect them from potential disruptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/02/the-day-of-departure-its-either-death-or-freedom.html|author=Chris Bodenner|title="The Day Of Departure": Calm But Determined|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=}}</ref> The day's planned events began after prayers. Al Jazeera estimated the crowd size to be over one million in Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://www.demotix.com/news/579902/flags-egypt-raised-above-tahrir-square "Flags of Egypt raised above Tahrir Square"] ''Demotix - News By You'' - Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Protesters held portraits of former presidents [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Anwar Sadat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/05/stories/2011020565420100.htm |title=Front Page : Ball in Mubarak's court as democracy pressure mounts |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> However, protesters did not get to the presidential palace. In Alexandria, over a million protesters turned out, making it the biggest-ever protest there. They warned that if the government used violence against protesters in Cairo, they would march to Cairo to join the protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb" />
Two million Egyptians flooded Tahrir Square to participate in Friday prayer in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=235172|title=2 million Egyptians turn out for Day of Departure|publisher=[[Tehran Times]]|date=2011-02-05|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> [[Egyptian Christians]] and others not performing Friday prayers formed a "human chain" around those praying to protect them from potential disruptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/02/the-day-of-departure-its-either-death-or-freedom.html|author=Chris Bodenner|title="The Day Of Departure": Calm But Determined|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=}}</ref> The day's planned events began after prayers. Al Jazeera estimated the crowd size to be over one million in Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://www.demotix.com/news/579902/flags-egypt-raised-above-tahrir-square "Flags of Egypt raised above Tahrir Square"] ''Demotix - News By You'' - Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Protesters held portraits of former presidents [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Anwar Sadat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/05/stories/2011020565420100.htm |title=Front Page : Ball in Mubarak's court as democracy pressure mounts |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> However, protesters did not get to the presidential palace. In Alexandria, over a million protesters turned out, making it the biggest-ever protest there. They warned that if the government used violence against protesters in Cairo, they would march to Cairo to join the protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb" />
